cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: Grabbing at the front brake or jamming down on the rear brake:
questions.answerA: Can cause the brakes to lock.
questions.answerB: Is the best way to stop in an emergency.
questions.answerC: Is the best way to slow down when the streets are wet.
questions.explanation: Grabbing at the front brake or jamming down on the rear brake can cause the brakes to lock. This may result in control problems.

questions.question: Before a ride, a motorcycle operator should check the throttle. The throttle should:
questions.answerA: Stay in place when released.
questions.answerB: Stay loose when released.
questions.answerC: Snap back when released.
questions.explanation: Check your clutch and throttle before riding your motorcycle. The throttle should snap back when you let go and the clutch should feel tight and smooth.

questions.question: Using all three lane positions is:
questions.answerA: Not encouraged because then you can never get used to any part of a lane.
questions.answerB: Discouraged because it confuses other motorists.
questions.answerC: Wise if you are adapting to changing conditions.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. Vary your lane position as road and traffic conditions warrant.

questions.question: Most motorcycle/automobile accidents occur:
questions.answerA: At intersections.
questions.answerB: On the open road.
questions.answerC: In parking lots.
questions.explanation: Most collisions between motorcycles and automobiles take place at intersections. The most common cause of these accidents is the automobile operator failing to properly yield the right-of-way to the motorcyclist.

questions.question: One problem with a motorcyclist riding directly next to another vehicle is that:
questions.answerA: The other vehicle may block the motorcyclist's escape route.
questions.answerB: The motorcyclist can be easily seen by other drivers.
questions.answerC: The motorcyclist may not be able to read signs on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: Riding alongside another vehicle is dangerous because the vehicle could veer into your lane and sideswipe you. Additionally, the vehicle could block your escape route if a hazard arises.

questions.question: The human body removes alcohol at a rate of:
questions.answerA: About one drink per hour.
questions.answerB: About two drinks per hour.
questions.answerC: About three drinks per hour.
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can remove the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. This rate can vary based on the individual. The safest option is to not ride after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: To minimize the potential for fatigue, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on the radio.
questions.answerB: Take frequent rest breaks.
questions.answerC: Drink caffeine.
questions.explanation: Taking frequent rest breaks during a long trip can help reduce fatigue. Stimulants, such as caffeine, can ultimately increase the danger of fatigue because you may become extremely tired when they begin to wear off. Wind, rain, snow, and other elements can also increase levels of fatigue, so dress warmly (as needed) and invest in a windshield, especially if you plan to ride long distances.

questions.question: If another driver makes eye contact with you:
questions.answerA: You know that they have seen you.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t always mean they've actually seen you.
questions.answerC: They will properly yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never rely on eye contact as an assurance that a driver has seen you. It is not uncommon for a driver to look directly at a motorcyclist and still fail to actually notice them.

questions.question: What can remove alcohol from a person's system?
questions.answerA: Time
questions.answerB: Coffee
questions.answerC: Exercise
questions.explanation: The only way to sober up after drinking is to give your body the time it needs to remove the alcohol. There are no techniques that will speed up this process.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Not make sudden movements, if possible.
questions.answerB: Handle your motorcycle roughly.
questions.answerC: Use only your front brake.
questions.explanation: On a slippery surface, any sudden change in speed or direction could cause a skid. Accelerate, shift gears, turn, and brake as smoothly as you can when riding on a slippery surface.

questions.question: How can you get sober after drinking alcohol?
questions.answerA: Wait.
questions.answerB: Drink coffee.
questions.answerC: Exercise.
questions.explanation: The only way to sober up after drinking is to give your body the time it needs to remove the alcohol. There are no techniques that will speed up this process.

questions.question: How many alcoholic drinks need to be consumed before the drinker's riding ability is affected?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.explanation: As little as one alcoholic drink can have a significant effect on your ability to safely operate a motor vehicle. It is never a safe choice to ride after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between you and other vehicles?
questions.answerA: At intersections
questions.answerB: On the highway
questions.answerC: On any road
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between motorcycles and other traffic is at intersections. Oncoming cars turning left in front of motorcyclists is the biggest danger.

questions.question: You have an improved chance of surviving a crash if you wear:
questions.answerA: A DOT-compliant helmet.
questions.answerB: A baseball cap.
questions.answerC: Comfortable shoes.
questions.explanation: You will get the most head and neck protection from a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. The single most effective thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving a crash is wear a properly secured, good-quality helmet.

questions.question: If you must transport a load, it should be:
questions.answerA: Carried over the rear axle.
questions.answerB: Carried on the gas tank in front of you.
questions.answerC: Piled up against a sissy bar or frame on the back of the seat.
questions.explanation: Loads should be kept over, or in front of, the rear axle. Only experienced riders should carry loads on their motorcycle.

questions.question: To control a motorcycle well, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your arms to hold yourself up.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank.
questions.answerC: Sit so your arms are straight when reaching for the handlebars.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should be seated so you can use your arms to steer rather than to hold yourself up. Your elbows should be slightly bent when you hold the handgrips. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance.

questions.question: The faster you drink alcohol:
questions.answerA: The faster the alcohol is removed from your body.
questions.answerB: The faster the alcohol accumulates in your body.
questions.answerC: The less the alcohol affects your body.
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the faster the alcohol will accumulate in your body. Alcohol leaves a person's system at an average of one drink per hour. If you consume more than one drink in an hour, you will still have alcohol in your body after one hour has passed.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should attempt to avoid obstacles on the roadway. If avoiding an obstacle is not possible, the motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Speed up before coming into contact with the object.
questions.answerB: Stay seated so the seat can cushion some of the impact.
questions.answerC: Try to approach the obstacle at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible.
questions.explanation: If you are unable to avoid an obstacle and must instead ride over it, you should slow down and approach the obstacle at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible.

questions.question: Which colors are the best colors for motorcycle riders to wear?
questions.answerA: Brown, gold, silver, and white
questions.answerB: Blue, black, gray, and purple
questions.answerC: Orange, red, yellow, and green
questions.explanation: Bright oranges, reds, yellows, and greens are the best colors for motorcyclists to wear. These colors can help other road users see motorcyclists.

questions.question: Under normal riding conditions, one of the best ways to help others see your motorcycle is:
questions.answerA: To flash your lights.
questions.answerB: To keep your high beam headlight turned on.
questions.answerC: To ensure that your motorcycle is painted a dark color.
questions.explanation: The best way to help others see your motorcycle is to have your headlight turned on (as well as your running lights, if applicable). Use your high beam headlight both day and night, whenever it is legal and safe to do so.

questions.question: When traveling at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride as fast as you would if riding during the day.
questions.answerB: Ride more slowly than you would if riding during the day.
questions.answerC: Ride faster than you would if riding during the day.
questions.explanation: When traveling at night, ride more slowly than you would if riding during the day, especially when traveling on an unfamiliar road. Riding more slowly allows you additional time to avoid hazards under conditions of decreased visibility.

questions.question: When riding behind another vehicle, you should position yourself:
questions.answerA: To be seen in the vehicle’s side mirror.
questions.answerB: To be seen in the vehicle’s rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: To be seen through the vehicle's passenger window.
questions.explanation: If you are following a car, the driver is most likely to notice you if you position yourself behind them in the center of your lane. This lane position places you in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors.

questions.question: When being passed, moving to the part of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle:
questions.answerA: Is recommended because you will be farther away from the passing vehicle.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended because it invites the other driver to move back into your lane too early.
questions.answerC: Is not encouraged or discouraged as it has no impact on safety.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is not advisable to move to the part of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle. Doing so may prompt the passing driver to move back into your lane too early.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, your feet should be:
questions.answerA: On the footrests for balance.
questions.answerB: Pointed with your toes aiming downward.
questions.answerC: Relaxed.
questions.explanation: When riding, your feet should be kept firmly on your motorcycle's footrests for balance. Your toes should not be pointed downward, as this may cause them to get caught between the road and the footrests.

questions.question: When selecting a jacket that will be used as protective apparel, a motorcycle rider should look for a jacket that is:
questions.answerA: Black, or another dark color.
questions.answerB: Warm.
questions.answerC: Made of leather or synthetic materials.
questions.explanation: When riding a motorcycle, it is highly recommended that you wear protective apparel. Look for a jacket that completely covers your arms and fits snugly but still allows you to move freely. Leather or sturdy synthetic materials with integrated body armor offer the best protection.

questions.question: When riding over grooved pavement in a work zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Look down to watch for changes in the road surface.
questions.answerB: Keep your head and eyes up.
questions.answerC: Move to the edge of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Keep your head and eyes up when riding through a work zone. Ride slowly over the grooved pavement.

questions.question: If you borrow a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume all controls are in the same location as they are on your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Immediately take it out on the highway.
questions.answerC: Get familiar with it in a controlled area.
questions.explanation: All motorcycles are at least somewhat different. Before riding a motorcycle that is new to you, take the time to learn where all of the controls are. Ride the motorcycle in a controlled area to get used to it before taking it out on the road.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerA: Hold onto the rider's hips, waist, or belt.
questions.answerB: Never hold onto the rider.
questions.answerC: Not lean into any turn.
questions.explanation: Before beginning your ride, tell your passenger to maintain a firm grasp on your hips, waist, or belt. If there are secure handholds for your passenger, they may also hold those.

questions.question: Motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Need less room to stop than other larger vehicles.
questions.answerB: Need as much room to stop as other larger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Can stop instantly.
questions.explanation: A rider should always maintain a cushion of space appropriate for conditions. Motorcycles need as much room to stop as other vehicles.

questions.question: When entering a turn, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Change gears before the turn.
questions.answerB: Change gears during the turn.
questions.answerC: Take the motorcycle out of gear.
questions.explanation: It is best to change gears before entering a turn. If you must change gears while in a turn, be sure to do so smoothly.

questions.question: To properly control a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow your feet to hang off the footrests.
questions.answerB: Sit so your arms hold up your body.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees against the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should be positioned so that you are able to easily operate all controls. Sit with your arms slightly bent and use your arms to steer rather than to hold up your body. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance during turns.

questions.question: The proper action to take when riding an unfamiliar motorcycle for the first time is to:
questions.answerA: Just start riding. There is no better way to learn than by doing.
questions.answerB: Just start riding. Most bikes are similar, so you don’t have to take the time to identify safety features.
questions.answerC: Work the throttle, clutch, and brakes before riding to learn the bike's gear pattern.
questions.explanation: Every bike is a little different, so don't start riding an unfamiliar motorcycle without first familiarizing yourself with how it operates. Do a safety and maintenance check; find out where everything is located; and work the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times to learn its gear pattern.

questions.question: If your front wheel locks while you are braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the tire locked up, as it will help you stop more quickly.
questions.answerB: Release the front brake and only use the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake immediately and re-apply it.
questions.explanation: If the front wheel locks up while you are braking, release the pressure from the front brake. Immediately re-apply pressure to the brake with controlled gradual pressure.

questions.question: Riding gloves should be made of:
questions.answerA: Leather.
questions.answerB: Wool.
questions.answerC: Any soft material.
questions.explanation: To provide maximum grip and protection, riding gloves should be made of leather or a similar durable material.

questions.question: How do convex mirrors differ from regular mirrors?
questions.answerA: They provide a more narrow view of the road.
questions.answerB: They provide a wider view of the road.
questions.answerC: They provide a better view of the road.
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors are installed on many motorcycles. Compared to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road. However, convex mirrors can also make approaching vehicles seem farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Scan your path ahead.
questions.answerB: Be ready to act to avoid a hazard.
questions.answerC: Turn your headlight off during the day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked cars, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride on the left side of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride wherever you are most comfortable.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, the left portion of the lane is generally safest for travel. This position will help you avoid hazards like doors being opened, people stepping out from between the parked cars, and cars pulling out of parking spaces. Always be ready to adjust your lane position to respond to changing road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: If possible, do not ride directly next to another vehicle because:
questions.answerA: Another driver may want to use your lane to pass.
questions.answerB: You may be in the vehicle’s blind spot.
questions.answerC: You may have access to escape routes.
questions.explanation: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is dangerous because you may be in the vehicle's blind spot and the driver will not know you are there. Additionally, the vehicle may block your route of escape if any hazards should arise.

questions.question: There may be less traction available for braking when:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle is leaning.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle is straight up and down.
questions.answerC: A motorcycle is on dry pavement.
questions.explanation: Any time a motorcycle is leaning, such as in a turn or curve, there is less traction available for braking. Both brakes may still be used while a motorcycle is turning, but it must be done with great care.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, a motorcycle rider has an advantage over an automobile driver because:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle can accelerate more quickly than a car.
questions.answerB: The motorcyclist can ride in the left part of the lane to avoid people and cars to their right.
questions.answerC: Motorcycles have a shorter stopping distance than cars do.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked vehicles to your right, you may ride in the left portion of your lane. This way, you can more easily avoid opening doors, drivers getting out of vehicles, or people stepping out from between vehicles. Only ride in the left portion of the lane if there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If your rear wheel locks up while you are stopping on a straightaway:
questions.answerA: You can usually maintain control of the motorcycle.
questions.answerB: You will likely lose control of the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: You will need to release the rear brake to regain control of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock your rear wheel while stopping on a straightaway, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped. Even with a locked rear wheel, you can usually control your motorcycle if it is upright and traveling in a straight line.

questions.question: Oil drippings and debris often collect in ______ of a lane.
questions.answerA: The left portion
questions.answerB: The middle portion
questions.answerC: The right portion
questions.explanation: Oil drippings and debris from cars and trucks often collect in the center portion of a lane.

questions.question: If you are riding behind another vehicle at night, you can determine if there are bumps on the road ahead by:
questions.answerA: Listening for the other vehicle scraping against the pavement.
questions.answerB: Noticing the other vehicle’s taillights bouncing up and down.
questions.answerC: Looking at the rear bumper of the vehicle ahead and trying to determine if it is bouncing.
questions.explanation: To determine upcoming road conditions when riding at night, use the vehicle ahead of you. For example, the headlights of the vehicle may provide a better view of the road than your own high beam. If the vehicle's taillights bounce up and down, this indicates the presence of bumps on the road.

questions.question: If you must stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerA: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerB: Use the front brake first.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake at the same time as the rear brake.
questions.explanation: The best way to stop quickly is to apply controlled pressure to both the rear and front brakes at the same time. Be careful not to lock the brakes in the process.

questions.question: The best footwear for motorcyclists are:
questions.answerA: Sneakers.
questions.answerB: Sturdy boots.
questions.answerC: Sandals.
questions.explanation: Leather boots provide the greatest degree of foot protection when riding. Boots should be high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can protect you from:
questions.answerA: Noise.
questions.answerB: Dust.
questions.answerC: Glare.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can protect your face in the event of a crash. It also provides protection against more routine hazards, such as pebbles thrown up from other vehicles, wind, dust, dirt, rain, and insects.

questions.question: Motorcycles may pass on the right:
questions.answerA: If there is at least eight feet of unobstructed pavement.
questions.answerB: By riding on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerC: By riding on the grass, if it is level.
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists may pass on the right if there is unobstructed pavement with a width of at least eight feet to the right of the vehicle being passed. Motorcyclists, and other drivers, should never leave the road to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: If you have only one drink before riding:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: It can affect your ability to operate a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Impairment of riding skills begins with the first drink. If you have consumed alcohol in any amount, it is not safe to ride.

questions.question: The risk of a head or neck injury is reduced:
questions.answerA: By wearing a helmet.
questions.answerB: By riding more slowly.
questions.answerC: By reading the owner’s manual.
questions.explanation: A head or neck injury is always a risk when riding a motorcycle, regardless of your speed of travel. With few exceptions, the risk of head and neck injuries is greatly reduced by properly wearing a quality helmet.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes occur:
questions.answerA: In broad daylight.
questions.answerB: At dusk.
questions.answerC: At night.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight. Wearing bright colors and reflective materials is always recommended when riding, even during the day.

questions.question: The formation you should take when riding in a group:
questions.answerA: Is always single-file.
questions.answerB: Depends on the situation.
questions.answerC: Is always staggered.
questions.explanation: In general, it is best for a group to ride in a staggered formation. Move into a single-file formation when taking a curve, making a turn, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.

questions.question: Which factor does not play a major role in affecting your blood alcohol content (BAC)?
questions.answerA: Age
questions.answerB: The amount of alcohol consumed
questions.answerC: Body weight
questions.explanation: Factors that play an important role in determining a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) include the amount of alcohol consumed, how fast it was consumed, and the person's body weight.

questions.question: When cars are merging from an entrance ramp:
questions.answerA: A motorcyclist should assume the entering drivers see them.
questions.answerB: A motorcyclist should never assume the entering drivers see them.
questions.answerC: A motorcyclist should stop.
questions.explanation: Always allow merging cars plenty of space and never assume that the drivers see you. Change lanes away from the entering traffic, if possible. If there is no room for a lane change, adjust your speed to allow for safe merging.

questions.question: What does a solid yellow traffic light mean?
questions.answerA: The traffic light is about to change to red.
questions.answerB: The traffic light is about to change to green.
questions.answerC: Stop and wait for traffic to pass.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow traffic light warns that the signal is about to change to red. You must slow and come to a stop before the intersection if it is safe to do so. If you are already within the intersection when the light turns yellow, continue through the intersection.

questions.question: In general, which position within a lane is the best to ride in?
questions.answerA: The left position
questions.answerB: The right position
questions.answerC: There is no single best lane position.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. A responsible rider adjusts their position as conditions change.

questions.question: For motorcycle operators, eye protection is:
questions.answerA: Required.
questions.answerB: Not required, but recommended.
questions.answerC: Not recommended.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle operators are required to use proper eye protection when riding in Georgia.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger, a motorcycle responds to directional changes:
questions.answerA: More slowly than usual.
questions.answerB: More quickly than usual.
questions.answerC: Normally.
questions.explanation: A passenger places extra weight on a motorcycle. Because of the added weight, the motorcycle will respond to the operator's movements more slowly than it would otherwise, taking more time to speed up, slow down, and turn.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: Signal ahead
questions.answerB: Crossroad ahead
questions.answerC: Divided roadway ahead
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions. This warning sign indicates a divided roadway ahead.

questions.question: You approach an emergency vehicle that is stopped on the side of the road while using its flashing lights. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop on the roadway behind the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop and wait until the emergency vehicle begins moving again.
questions.answerC: Merge into a lane away from the emergency vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you approach an emergency vehicle, tow truck, or roadside assistance vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing, you must change lanes to allow the vehicle extra space and proceed with caution. Always slow down and be prepared to stop when you approach an emergency scene.

questions.question: When looking through a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head.
questions.answerC: Turn your head, shoulders, and torso.
questions.explanation: Look through every turn by turning just your head, not your shoulders, and keeping your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Before riding, a motorcycle operator should check the clutch. A properly working clutch should feel:
questions.answerA: Loose and rough.
questions.answerB: Tight and smooth.
questions.answerC: Loose and smooth.
questions.explanation: Check your clutch and throttle before riding your motorcycle. The throttle should snap back when you let go and the clutch should feel tight and smooth.

questions.question: If you are being passed, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, the center portion of the lane is generally the safest lane position for a motorcyclist. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with it. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle can also be dangerous because it may prompt the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You will get the most protection from a helmet if it is all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: U.S. DOT-compliant.
questions.answerB: Loose-fitting.
questions.answerC: Free of defects.
questions.explanation: A helmet will provide a rider with the best protection if it meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards; fits snugly all the way around; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: You should maintain an increased following distance:
questions.answerA: If the pavement is slippery.
questions.answerB: If traffic is light.
questions.answerC: If you can see through the vehicles in front of you to determine traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a minimum four-second following distance.

questions.question: A person with a minimum blood alcohol content (BAC) of ____ is considered intoxicated.
questions.answerA: 0.02 percent
questions.answerB: 0.04 percent
questions.answerC: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: In Virginia, a person with a blood alcohol content (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered intoxicated. Any intoxicated person is prohibited from operating a motor vehicle.

questions.question: When other vehicles are slowed or stopped:
questions.answerA: A motorcyclist should not weave between lanes of traffic.
questions.answerB: It is acceptable for a motorcyclist to weave in and out of traffic lanes.
questions.answerC: A motorcyclist should ride in a straight line between two lanes.
questions.explanation: Riding between rows of stopped or slowly moving vehicles can be dangerous. Vehicles may change lanes, doors may open, or arms may be stuck out of vehicles' windows. Despite their size, motorcycles need the full width of a lane to operate safely.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Yield to other drivers.
questions.answerC: A stop sign is ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions. This sign warns that a stop sign is ahead.

questions.question: Alcohol reaches the brain ________ being consumed.
questions.answerA: Within minutes of
questions.answerB: About an hour after
questions.answerC: About two hours after
questions.explanation: Alcohol reaches the brain and begins affecting the drinker's riding abilities within minutes of being consumed. Operating any motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol is illegal and dangerous.

questions.question: When riding over scored pavement in a work zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Look downward to see the changes in the road surface.
questions.answerB: Keep your head and eyes up.
questions.answerC: Stay to the left side of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding over scored pavement in a work zone, keep your head and eyes up. Ride slowly, keep a steady throttle, and don't try to fight the handlebars.

questions.question: Long-term exposure to wind noise:
questions.answerA: Is not a danger.
questions.answerB: Can cause irreversible hearing damage.
questions.answerC: Is just part of riding a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Long-term exposure to wind noise can cause permanent damage to your hearing. Using ear protection when you ride should protect you from the dangers of wind noise while still allowing you to hear important sounds, like sirens or car horns.

questions.question: If vehicles or other potential hazards are to your right, you should ride on which side of your lane?
questions.answerA: Right
questions.answerB: Left
questions.answerC: Either side
questions.explanation: When riding on the road, position yourself in a manner that allows you the most possible space. If there are hazards to your left, ride on the right side of your lane. If there are hazards to you right, ride on the left side of your lane.

questions.question: A sign that your rear tire has suddenly gone flat is that:
questions.answerA: The back of your motorcycle is swaying from side to side.
questions.answerB: You heard a loud noise.
questions.answerC: A discharge of air can be seen.
questions.explanation: If the rear tire of a motorcycle goes flat, the back of the motorcycle may jerk or sway from side to side. If you experience this movement when riding your motorcycle, you should stop riding and check your tires as soon as possible.

questions.question: When riding with a group of motorcyclists, a staggered formation:
questions.answerA: Is recommended at all times.
questions.answerB: Should not be used when entering or exiting a highway.
questions.answerC: Should be used when riding in curves.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is generally advisable, a group of motorcyclists should switch to a single-file formation when riding in curves, turning, and entering or leaving a highway.

questions.question: The best clothing for a motorcyclist:
questions.answerA: Feels uncomfortable.
questions.answerB: Provides protection in a crash.
questions.answerC: Should not stand out to other motorists.
questions.explanation: Properly chosen clothing for riding provides a rider with protection in the event of a crash while keeping the rider comfortable and ensuring that they are visible to other road users.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerC: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.explanation: Ride with extreme caution when approaching an intersection. Cover the clutch and both brakes to reduce your reaction time, if needed.

questions.question: If traveling with a load, the load should be:
questions.answerA: Secured as low as possible.
questions.answerB: Secured as high as possible.
questions.answerC: Attached to a sissy bar.
questions.explanation: If not carried in saddlebags, loads should be secured as low as possible. Attaching a load to a sissy bar can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and upset its balance.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection, a motorcyclist should not:
questions.answerA: Choose a lane position that increases their visibility.
questions.answerB: Speed up to cross the intersection quickly.
questions.answerC: Cover the clutch and brakes to reduce their reaction time.
questions.explanation: As you approach an intersection, select a lane position that will make you the most visible to other drivers and cover the clutch and both brakes to reduce your reaction time. Reduce your speed when approaching an intersection. Avoid changing your speed or position radically as doing so may cause surrounding drivers to misinterpret your intentions.

questions.question: When stopping, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both brakes.
questions.answerB: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerC: Use the rear brake only.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes every time you slow or stop. It is important to be able to brake quickly by using both brakes.

questions.question: When sitting on a motorcycle, your arms should:
questions.answerA: Have a large bend at the elbow when reaching for the handle grips.
questions.answerB: Be slightly bent when holding the handle grips.
questions.answerC: Be fully extended when reaching for the handle grips.
questions.explanation: Your arms should be slightly bent when you are holding the handle grips of a motorcycle. Bending your arms reduces arm fatigue and permits you to press on the handlebars without having to stretch.

questions.question: If you approach an uncontrolled intersection at the same time as another vehicle:
questions.answerA: The vehicle on the left should yield to the vehicle on the right.
questions.answerB: You should flash your headlight to signal that the other vehicle should proceed.
questions.answerC: You should continue through the intersection and expect the other vehicle to stop.
questions.explanation: If you approach an intersection that is not marked with signs or traffic lights at the same time as another driver, the driver on the left must yield to the driver on the right.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between you and other vehicles?
questions.answerA: At an intersection
questions.answerB: On the highway
questions.answerC: On any road
questions.explanation: The potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other vehicles is greatest at intersections.

questions.question: Wearing which of the following colors will make you less visible to other motorists?
questions.answerA: Orange
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.answerC: Brown
questions.explanation: To make yourself more visible to other road users, it is best if you choose to wear bright orange, red, yellow, or green clothing. Avoid wearing drab or dark colors while riding.

questions.question: Mirrors on motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Have blind spots, just like cars.
questions.answerB: Do not have blind spots because a motorcycle is usually smaller than a car
questions.answerC: Are not required.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like cars. You should always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear half-fingered gloves.
questions.answerB: Wear full-fingered gloves.
questions.answerC: Not wear gloves.
questions.explanation: Wearing gloves while riding provides an improved grip and help protect your hands. You should use gloves that are full-fingered and made of a durable material.

questions.question: If the front wheel locks, you should:
questions.answerA: Release the front brake immediately, then re-apply the brake.
questions.answerB: Release the front brake immediately and only use the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Keep the front wheel locked until you come to a stop.
questions.explanation: If you lock the front wheel while braking, release the brake and immediately re-apply it.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Move into the portion of the lane that will bring you into another driver’s field of vision at the earliest possible moment.
questions.answerB: Stop at the stop sign or signal and then proceed normally.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights and sound your horn to alert other drivers to your presence.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection, move into the portion of the lane that will bring you into another driver’s field of vision at the earliest possible moment.

questions.question: The oily strip down the center of a lane:
questions.answerA: Should only be traveled upon if you are sharing the lane with another vehicle.
questions.answerB: Usually provides adequate traction for riding, unless it is raining.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided at all times.
questions.explanation: While the center strip of the road can be oily, it usually provides enough traction for safe riding, unless it is raining. The oily strip is usually no more than two feet wide, so motorcyclists can generally ride on either side of the strip and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Having only one alcoholic drink before riding:
questions.answerA: Will not lead to a DUI conviction.
questions.answerB: Will never affect your riding skills.
questions.answerC: Can affect your ability to operate a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Impairment of your ability to ride safely begins with the first drink you take. You can be convicted of riding impaired even if you are below the legal blood alcohol limit.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a method used to maintain control of a motorcycle in a turn?
questions.answerA: Accelerate through the turn.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed before turning.
questions.answerC: Lean into the turn.
questions.explanation: To ensure control when making a turn, you should reduce your speed before entering the turn. Look through the turn in the direction you want to move, press on the handle grip to lean in the appropriate direction, and roll on the throttle through the turn to stabilize suspension.

questions.question: When making a U-turn:
questions.answerA: The front and rear brakes need to be used at the same time.
questions.answerB: Do not use the front brake because it could cause the bike to tip over.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake to increase stability of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: The front brake should not be used when making a U-turn because it could cause the bike to tip over. Instead, use the rear brake to control the speed of the bike in the U-turn.

questions.question: When riding ________, you are facing the greatest potential for conflict between you and other vehicles.
questions.answerA: On the expressway
questions.answerB: Near an intersection
questions.answerC: In a group
questions.explanation: Intersections present the greatest potential for conflict between motorcycles and other vehicles. When approaching an intersection, be sure you are riding in a lane position that makes you most visible to other road users.

questions.question: To make it easier to be seen by other motorists, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear brightly-colored clothing while riding.
questions.answerB: Wear darkly-colored clothing while riding.
questions.answerC: Wave your arms while riding.
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing while riding will make it easier for others on the road to see you. This is true regardless of the time of day.

questions.question: Should you wear gloves while riding a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: Yes. Your hands may cold while riding.
questions.answerB: Yes. They provide an improved grip and help protect your hands.
questions.answerC: No. Gloves are not recommended as they can interfere with the controls.
questions.explanation: Wearing gloves while riding provides an improved grip and help protect your hands. You should use gloves that are full-fingered and made of a durable material.

questions.question: Stopping in a turn can be difficult because:
questions.answerA: There is decreased traction available for stopping while the bike is leaning.
questions.answerB: The rider is usually focused on the turn and not on the braking.
questions.answerC: The brake controls do not work in turns.
questions.explanation: It is possible to use both brakes while turning, but it must be done with great care. Some of the usual traction is being used to make the turn while the motorcycle is leaning, so less traction is available for stopping.

questions.question: When being followed by a tailgater, you should:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass or slow down to allow for more space ahead of your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Ignore them.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed by a tailgater, you should ride in a way that encourages them to pass you. Riding at a higher speed may only result in them tailgating you at a higher speed, increasing the danger.

questions.question: If you get a flat tire while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Hold the handle grips firmly and stay off the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good wheel and brake normally.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good wheel while immediately pulling off the road.
questions.explanation: If a tire goes flat while you are riding, hold onto the handgrips firmly and concentrate on maintaining a straight course. Brake only if you are sure which tire is flat. Exit the roadway once your motorcycle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: Riding on ______ may provide poor traction.
questions.answerA: Pavement markings
questions.answerB: Dry pavement
questions.answerC: The roadway under a bridge
questions.explanation: Traction may be poor on surfaces such as wet, snowy, icy, or muddy pavement; gravel roads; lane markings; and steel plates and utility hole covers.

questions.question: The Motorcycle Safety Foundation recommends a SEE strategy to make safe judgments while riding. What does "SEE" stand for?
questions.answerA: Search, Evaluate, and Execute.
questions.answerB: Slow, Experienced, and Error-free.
questions.answerC: Safe, Experienced, and Evasive.
questions.explanation: Experienced riders use a SEE strategy while riding to make safe judgements. "SEE" stands for Search, Evaluate, and Execute.

questions.question: You have an improved chance of avoiding serious injury in a crash if you wear all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A DOT-compliant helmet.
questions.answerB: A leather jacket.
questions.answerC: A sweatshirt.
questions.explanation: Wearing a U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)-compliant helmet can help protect you against head and neck injuries in the event of a crash. A jacket made of leather or sturdy synthetic material can also protect you against injuries.

questions.question: The best way to stay out of trouble while riding a motorcycle is to:
questions.answerA: Look well ahead of your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Avoid high-density traffic areas.
questions.answerC: Ride at speeds faster than the speed limit.
questions.explanation: To avoid running into dangerous situations while riding, you should consistently scan the road well ahead of your motorcycle. Watch the road ahead to identify and react to potential hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: Slippery when wet
questions.answerB: Lanes shift
questions.answerC: Yield
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions. This sign warns that the roadway ahead is likely to be slippery when wet.

questions.question: To reduce the chances of a collision, a motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Stare straight in front of their motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Be unwilling to move to avoid a potential hazard.
questions.answerC: Scan their path of travel, looking at least 10 to 15 seconds ahead of their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a collision, consistently scan your path of travel at least 10 to 15 seconds ahead of your motorcycle. Scanning the road ahead will give you time to react to a hazard before meeting the hazard.

questions.question: When braking on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: The rear brake should be applied first.
questions.answerB: The front brake should be applied first.
questions.answerC: The front and rear brakes should be applied at the same time.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes every time you slow down or stop. If you use only the rear brake when stopping normally, you may not develop the habit or the skill to use the front brake properly when you really need to stop quickly.

questions.question: If your rear wheel locks up while you are stopping on a surface with good traction, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the wheel locked until you have stopped completely.
questions.answerB: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake and then quickly re-apply the brake.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear wheel while stopping on a surface with good traction, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped. Even with a locked rear wheel, you can control your motorcycle if it is upright and traveling in a straight line.

questions.question: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Safe because you are in a separate lane.
questions.answerB: Recommended because it blocks the wind.
questions.answerC: Not recommended because you may be in the driver's blind spot.
questions.explanation: It is not advisable to ride beside passenger vehicles or trucks. Doing so may place you in another vehicle's blind spot and the driver could move into your lane without realizing you are there.

questions.question: If you need to react to a hazard in the road, do not:
questions.answerA: Avoid communicating with other drivers.
questions.answerB: Adjust your speed accordingly.
questions.answerC: Make your presence known by sounding your horn and/or using lights or signals.
questions.explanation: To create more space and minimize the harm of any hazard, communicate your presence to other road users by using your horn, lights, and/or signals. Adjust your speed to be appropriate for the situation and adjust your lane position and/or direction of travel as needed.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger on your motorcycle, you should instruct the passenger to:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle before the engine starts.
questions.answerB: Sit as far back as possible on the bike.
questions.answerC: Not talk or move unnecessarily.
questions.explanation: Tell passengers to avoid unnecessary conversation or movement while on a moving motorcycle. Passengers should get onto a motorcycle only after the engine is started. They should sit as far forward as possible without crowding the operator.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Allow you to blend in with traffic.
questions.answerB: Provide an escape route.
questions.answerC: Encourage others to use your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: Railroad crossing ahead
questions.answerB: Yield
questions.answerC: Reduce speed
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions. This sign warns that a railroad crossing is ahead.

questions.question: Eye protection:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if your motorcycle is equipped with a windshield.
questions.answerB: Is only necessary when riding in bad weather.
questions.answerC: Should allow the rider a clear view to either side.
questions.explanation: Proper face/eye protection is required by law in the state of California. A face shield can protect your whole face in the event of a collision. An effective eye or face shield must allow the rider a clear view to either side.

questions.question: Before starting a turn, a motorcyclist should change gears to:
questions.answerA: Prevent a change in power in the middle of the turn.
questions.answerB: Be able to keep both hands on the handle grips during the turn.
questions.answerC: Prevent the motorcycle from slowing down.
questions.explanation: It is best to change gears before starting a turn. Shifting gears while in the turn can cause a sudden change in power to the rear wheel, causing a skid. If you must change gears while in a turn, change gears smoothly to best prevent skidding.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a potential problem?
questions.answerA: An upcoming change in road surface characteristics
questions.answerB: Surrounding traffic
questions.answerC: Conditions that do not appear to change as you approach
questions.explanation: Anticipate potential problems that can be created by factors on the roadway. Make a plan to reduce their risks.

questions.question: In the center of a traffic lane, there is usually an oily strip. Motorcyclists should:
questions.answerA: Avoid riding on the oil and grease buildup.
questions.answerB: Not worry about the oil and grease buildup.
questions.answerC: Search for the lane with the smallest amount of oil and grease buildup.
questions.explanation: Avoid riding on oil and grease buildup. Because the oily strip in the center of a lane is usually no more than two feet wide, it is often possible to stay to the left or right side of the oil and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: To be effective, eye or face shield protection must:
questions.answerA: Fasten securely.
questions.answerB: Restrict your vision to the sides so you can focus on the road ahead.
questions.answerC: Not allow eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: If riding during the day, you should wear:
questions.answerA: Brightly-colored clothing to increase your chances of being seen.
questions.answerB: Clothing of any color because other drivers can easily see you in daylight.
questions.answerC: Darkly-colored clothing to contrast with the bright sunlight.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes take place in broad daylight. You should always wear brightly-colored clothing to increase your visibility while riding, even during the day.

questions.question: When wearing a jacket for protection, the jacket should:
questions.answerA: Be loose-fitting and flap in the wind while riding.
questions.answerB: Fit snugly.
questions.answerC: Be uncomfortable.
questions.explanation: Clothing for riding should provide protection while keeping you comfortable. Jackets and pants should be snug enough that they do not flap in the wind, but not so snug that they restrict your movements.

questions.question: If you have a passenger aboard your motorcycle, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride at speeds that are slower than usual.
questions.answerB: Allow more distance to stop than usual.
questions.answerC: Tell the passenger to hold onto the back of the bike.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle that is carrying a passenger will handle differently than usual due to the added weight of the additional rider. An operator should ride at slower speeds and allow more time and distance to slow down and stop. A passenger should hold firmly and securely onto the motorcycle's passenger handgrips or onto the operator's waist, hips, or midsection.

questions.question: A DOT-compliant helmet:
questions.answerA: Severely limits your vision.
questions.answerB: Allows you to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding.
questions.answerC: Can become a hazard to the rider.
questions.explanation: While some people believe that a helmet will limit their vision, this is not the case. Any U.S. Department of Transportation-approved helmet will allow the wearer to see as far as is needed for safe riding.

questions.question: If riding during the day, you should wear:
questions.answerA: Clothing with reflective material.
questions.answerB: A short-sleeved shirt.
questions.answerC: Darkly-colored clothing.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight. To maximize your chances of being seen, you should wear clothing with reflective material when riding, even during the day. Always wear clothing that covers your arms and legs.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerA: Look over their shoulder when taking a turn or curve.
questions.answerB: Never hold onto the rider.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.explanation: Before mounting, you should ask your passenger to look over your shoulder in the direction of any turn or curve that you may take. Doing so will help you and your bike to lean in the appropriate direction.

questions.question: If your front wheel locks while you are braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the tire locked until your next stop.
questions.answerB: Continue squeezing the front brake lever.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake and immediately re-apply it.
questions.explanation: If the front wheel locks up while you are braking, release the pressure from the front brake. Immediately re-apply pressure to the brake with controlled gradual pressure.

questions.question: When being passed by another vehicle, you should travel in:
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, the center portion of the lane is generally the safest lane position for a motorcyclist. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with it. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle can also be dangerous because it may prompt the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If wearing a jacket for protection while riding in hot weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Take frequent breaks to cool off.
questions.answerB: Remove the jacket to stay cool while in the sun.
questions.answerC: Keep the jacket on to protect you from the heat.
questions.explanation: A sturdy riding jacket provides essential protection in the event of a crash, no matter the weather. Jackets also provide an additional benefit in hot weather by protecting the rider against dehydration. Many motorcycling jackets are designed to prevent the wearer from overheating.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection:
questions.answerA: Takes only minutes.
questions.answerB: Takes about an hour.
questions.answerC: Should only be done by a certified mechanic.
questions.explanation: You should do a pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This will usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: Right lane ends
questions.answerB: Left lane ends
questions.answerC: Traffic control device ahead
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions. This sign warns that the right lane ends ahead.

questions.question: Mirrors on motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Have blind spots, just like cars.
questions.answerB: Do not have blind spots.
questions.answerC: Are not required.
questions.explanation: The mirrors of motorcycles have blind spots, just like those of cars. Always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a potentially slippery surface?
questions.answerA: A gravel road
questions.answerB: A paved driveway
questions.answerC: Dry pavement
questions.explanation: Traction may be poor on surfaces such as wet, snowy, icy, or muddy pavement; gravel roads; lane markings; and steel plates and utility hole covers.

questions.question: When riding, your feet should be:
questions.answerA: On the gas tank.
questions.answerB: Hanging loosely.
questions.answerC: On the footrests.
questions.explanation: Your feet should remain on your footrests while riding to help you maintain proper balance.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Move closer to the vehicle in front of you so you can use its lights to see farther down the road.
questions.answerB: Keep riding at your normal speed to lower the risk of being struck from behind.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed and increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Visibility is lowered at night and you will need the additional time and space to react to upcoming hazards.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a benefit of maintaining a space cushion between your motorcycle and other vehicles?
questions.answerA: You will have time to react to hazards.
questions.answerB: You will have space to maneuver.
questions.answerC: You will have more time to accelerate when entering a curve.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times helps ensure that you will have time to react and space to maneuver if someone else on the road makes a mistake.

questions.question: You are most likely to get into a collision:
questions.answerA: At an intersection.
questions.answerB: When riding in a group.
questions.answerC: Traveling on the expressway.
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between you and other traffic exists at intersections.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid danger, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the front brake while swerving.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve, you should take these actions separately. Never brake while swerving because doing so can cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: When crossing angled railroad tracks, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Use the shoulder of the road to slow down before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: Walk your motorcycle across the tracks.
questions.answerC: Continue straight within your lane to cross the tracks.
questions.explanation: In most cases, it is safest to ride straight within your lane to cross angled railroad or trolley tracks. Changing the angle of your path to cross tracks may send you into another lane, causing a collision with oncoming traffic.

questions.question: When nearing a blind intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Assume that other drivers will properly yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Change your lane position to become more visible to other drivers.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection, move into the lane position that makes you the most visible to surrounding drivers.

questions.question: Which brake is more powerful on a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: The front brake
questions.answerB: The rear brake
questions.answerC: Both brakes are equally powerful.
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful that the rear brake and can provide at least 70 percent of the bike's total stopping power.

questions.question: When riding at night, maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerA: Two seconds.
questions.answerB: Three seconds.
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Because it can be difficult to judge distances in the dark, ride with a following distance of at least three seconds when traveling at night.

questions.question: Eye protection is:
questions.answerA: Required for all riders.
questions.answerB: Not required, but recommended.
questions.answerC: Only required for inexperienced motorcycle users.
questions.explanation: Georgia law requires a rider to wear eye protection when on a moving motorcycle. A full face shield provides a rider with the best possible protection.

questions.question: When riding, you should wear:
questions.answerA: Bright clothing.
questions.answerB: Dark clothing.
questions.answerC: Clothes that are uncomfortable.
questions.explanation: Wear brightly-colored clothing to maximize your visibility when riding, even during the daytime. Clothing made with reflective materials can also be helpful.

questions.question: How should a group of motorcyclists pass another vehicle?
questions.answerA: In a staggered formation
questions.answerB: In pairs
questions.answerC: One at a time
questions.explanation: On a two-lane road, a group of motorcyclists should pass another vehicle one at a time. Each motorcyclist should complete the pass before another begins to pass.

questions.question: The safest part of the lane:
questions.answerA: Is always the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Is always the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Changes depending on the situation.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. Adjust your lane position as circumstances warrant.

questions.question: Before starting out, you should make sure the fuel valve is:
questions.answerA: Open.
questions.answerB: Closed.
questions.answerC: Covered.
questions.explanation: Before setting out on a ride, you should make sure that your motorcycle's fuel supply valve is open. If the fuel valve is closed, the engine may still start with the fuel that is remaining in the lines from a previous ride, but it will stall once the lines are empty.

questions.question: When preparing to ride with a passenger, instruct the passenger to:
questions.answerA: Get onto the motorcycle before you.
questions.answerB: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Hold firmly onto your waist, hips, or belt.
questions.explanation: Ask your passenger to wait to mount the motorcycle until after you have started the engine. They should sit as far forward as possible without crowding you and firmly hold onto your waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: Who is required to wear a helmet on a moving motorcycle?
questions.answerA: Only passengers
questions.answerB: All motorcycle riders and passengers
questions.answerC: No one
questions.explanation: All riders and passengers are required to wear a helmet when riding a motorcycle, motor-driven cycle, or motorized bicycle.

questions.question: To execute a turn safely, a motorcycle rider should always:
questions.answerA: Lean in the direction of the curve.
questions.answerB: Slow down in the turn.
questions.answerC: Turn by using only the handle bars.
questions.explanation: When turning, you should always lean in the direction of the turn. Slow down before entering the turn.

questions.question: If passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: You may exceed the speed limit until the pass is complete.
questions.answerB: You may disregard no passing zone markings if you began the pass in a passing zone.
questions.answerC: You must observe the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: All passes must be completed within the posted speed limits and only in areas where passing is permitted.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Avoid making sudden moves, as doing so could cause a skid.
questions.answerB: Travel on the shoulder to be out of the way of traffic.
questions.answerC: Use only the rear brake because the front brake is ineffective on slippery surfaces.
questions.explanation: On a slippery surface, any sudden change in speed or direction could result in a skid. Be as smooth as possible when you speed up, shift gears, turn, or brake on such a surface.

questions.question: A sign that your front tire has gone flat is that your steering suddenly feels:
questions.answerA: Heavy.
questions.answerB: Loose.
questions.answerC: Soft.
questions.explanation: If steering suddenly feels heavy, it is possible that your front tire has gone flat. Stop riding and check your tires as soon as possible.

questions.question: A good way to handle a tailgater is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Allow them to get in front of you.
questions.answerC: Make gestures at them.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to allow them to pass you. Speeding up may only result in them continuing to tailgate you at the higher speed, which is even more dangerous.

questions.question: If using saddlebags to carry a load, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the bags as evenly as possible.
questions.answerB: Unevenly distribute weight into the saddlebags.
questions.answerC: Place as much weight as possible into one saddlebag.
questions.explanation: Saddlebags should be loaded with approximately equal weights. If a load is distributed unevenly between bags, it may cause the motorcycle to drift to one side.

questions.question: When you are being passed on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed on your left, you should ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding in the right portion of the lane can be dangerous as it may tempt the passing driver to re-enter your lane too quickly.

questions.question: On a motorcycle, which brake provides the most stopping power?
questions.answerA: The front brake
questions.answerB: The rear brake
questions.answerC: The emergency brake
questions.explanation: The front brake provides about three-quarters of a motorcycle's total stopping power. Use both the front and rear brakes every time you stop.

questions.question: When riding in a group, mirrors:
questions.answerA: Should be checked frequently by all riders.
questions.answerB: Should be used only by the lead rider.
questions.answerC: Should not be checked frequently because they can be a distraction.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, use your mirrors to keep an eye on the riders behind you and to confirm that the group is staying together.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerC: Decrease your following distance.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: If bright sunlight makes it difficult for drivers to see a motorcycle's mechanical turn signals, the rider should:
questions.answerA: Continue to use the mechanical turn signals.
questions.answerB: Honk their horn to inform other drivers of any upcoming turns.
questions.answerC: Use hand signals.
questions.explanation: Use hand signals when bright sunlight makes your mechanical signals difficult for other drivers to see. It is extremely important to clearly communicate with other road users.

questions.question: To reduce the chances of a collision, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear bright or reflective clothing.
questions.answerB: Change lanes frequently.
questions.answerC: Focus only on your riding, not on your surroundings.
questions.explanation: Wearing bright or reflective clothing can help make you more visible to other drivers and reduce your risk of being involved in a collision. Always maintain an awareness of surrounding drivers to better prepare yourself for their movements.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a factor in determining a person's blood alcohol content (BAC)?
questions.answerA: The amount of alcohol consumed
questions.answerB: How quickly the alcohol is consumed
questions.answerC: How often the person consumes alcohol
questions.explanation: The main factors that determine a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) are the person's body weight, how much alcohol is consumed, and how quickly the alcohol was consumed. It is always safest to not ride after consuming alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Protects your face, but not your eyes.
questions.answerB: Protects your eyes, but not your whole face.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield provides maximum protection for your entire face, including your eyes, in the event of a crash. A windshield is not an adequate substitute.

questions.question: If a motorcycle is towing a trailer, the motorcyclist's following distance should:
questions.answerA: Increase.
questions.answerB: Decrease.
questions.answerC: Be the same as it normally would be.
questions.explanation: A motorcyclist who is towing a trailer should increase their following distance. The added weight of the trailer means that the motorcycle will require more time to stop than it would otherwise.

questions.question: You are riding over bridge gratings and your motorcycle has begun to weave. You should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to get over the surface faster.
questions.answerB: Ride in a zigzagging motion.
questions.answerC: Maintain a steady speed and ride straight across the gratings.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle begins to weave while you are traveling over bridge gratings, you should simply maintain a steady speed and proceed straight across the surface. Trying to stay in your lane while riding in a zigzagging motion is dangerous.

questions.question: What should be your first consideration when buying a motorcycle helmet?
questions.answerA: Appearance
questions.answerB: Protection
questions.answerC: Price
questions.explanation: Protection should be your first consideration when buying a motorcycle helmet. Look for a helmet that fastens securely, fits correctly, and is DOT-compliant.

questions.question: Which of the following materials provides the best protection for motorcycle riders?
questions.answerA: Fleece
questions.answerB: Leather
questions.answerC: Denim
questions.explanation: Clothing made of leather or sturdy synthetic materials provide the greatest degree of protection for those riding motorcycles.

questions.question: Before every ride, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure your bike's brake lights work properly.
questions.answerB: Make sure the paint on the bike is not peeling.
questions.answerC: Make sure your bike is completely clean.
questions.explanation: Perform safety checks before every motorcycle ride. Test your brake controls individually to make sure each one activates the brake lights.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your mirrors and look over your shoulder.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors. You do not need to look over your shoulder unless you notice something unusual.
questions.answerC: Either use your mirrors or look over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, make sure no other drivers are going to be in your path. Do this by checking your mirrors and looking over your shoulder in the direction you want to move.

questions.question: A benefit of keeping a cushion of space between you and surrounding vehicles is that:
questions.answerA: You are better able to draft off of other vehicles.
questions.answerB: You will be able to stop quickly.
questions.answerC: You will have more time to react to the movements of other drivers.
questions.explanation: It is important to maintain a cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times. This way, if a hazard arises, you will have more time to respond to the hazard and more space to safely maneuver.

questions.question: When preparing to pass a vehicle on the left, you should ride in which portion of the lane?
questions.answerA: The left portion
questions.answerB: The center portion
questions.answerC: The right portion
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass a vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. Doing this will increase your line of vision and help drivers in the next lane anticipate your move.

questions.question: A motorcycle’s horn is ________ a passenger vehicle's horn.
questions.answerA: Louder than
questions.answerB: Quieter than
questions.answerC: About as loud as
questions.explanation: A motorcycle's horn is not as loud as the horns of other vehicles. Motorcyclists should use their horns where appropriate but should not rely on their horns to keep them safe.

questions.question: Improper braking:
questions.answerA: Usually has no consequences.
questions.answerB: Is a significant contributing factor to many motorcycle crashes.
questions.answerC: Should not be a concern, since the motorcycle has two brakes.
questions.explanation: Improper braking is a significant contributing factor to many motorcycle crashes. Using a proper braking technique is an important part of riding safely.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should position your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: In the outside of the curve.
questions.answerB: In the inside of the curve.
questions.answerC: Where you can most safely handle road and traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: All curves are different. When taking a curve, choose a lane position that is appropriate for conditions and adjust as needed.

questions.question: A motorized scooter can:
questions.answerA: Only be operated during the day.
questions.answerB: Be operated without a driver license.
questions.answerC: Be operated with any class of driver license.
questions.explanation: In California, motorized scooter can be used by anyone possessing any class of driver license.

questions.question: Smaller vehicles appear to be ________ and slower than they really are.
questions.answerA: Closer
questions.answerB: Farther away
questions.answerC: Larger
questions.explanation: It can be difficult to judge the speed and distance of a small vehicle, such as a motorcycle. Do not assume that drivers of larger vehicles will be able to accurately understand your speed and location.

questions.question: Part of your normal scanning routine while riding should include:
questions.answerA: Constantly looking in the rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Frequent rearview mirror checks.
questions.answerC: Not using the rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Frequent mirror checks should be part of your normal scanning routine. Additionally, make a special point of using your mirrors before changing lanes, when stopping at an intersection, and before slowing down.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Provide a narrow view of the road behind you.
questions.answerB: Provide a wide view of the road behind you.
questions.answerC: Are illegal.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. Take the time to get used to your mirrors if your motorcycle is equipped with convex mirrors.

questions.question: When attempting to pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride within the posted speed limits.
