questions.answerB: Exceed the posted speed limit to complete the pass, but not by more than 10 mph.
questions.answerC: Pass more than one vehicle at a time.
questions.explanation: All passes must be completed within legal speed limits. Riders should pass only where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: As a rider, you can lessen your chances of being involved in an accident by:
questions.answerA: Not looking ahead for hazards.
questions.answerB: Refraining from using turn signals, as doing so could distract other drivers.
questions.answerC: Being visible to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision, be sure to make yourself visible, clearly communicate your intentions, maintain an adequate space cushion, search your path of travel, and identify and separate hazards. Always be prepared to react to any hazard that could arise.

questions.question: Upshifting or downshifting in a curve:
questions.answerA: Should only be done if it can be done smoothly.
questions.answerB: Is better than shifting before the curve.
questions.answerC: Is the best way to control your speed.
questions.explanation: It is best to change gears before starting a turn. However, if you must shift while turning, shift smoothly. A sudden change in power to the rear wheel can cause a skid.

questions.question: When passing a vehicle, you:
questions.answerA: May exceed the speed limit by 10 mph.
questions.answerB: Must not exceed the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Are required to ride faster than the speed limit.
questions.explanation: Passing must be completed within posted speed limits. Only pass another vehicle where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: No left turn
questions.answerB: No U-turn
questions.answerC: No right turn
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs are white signs with red and black markings that inform drivers of specific traffic laws in the indicated area. This sign indicates that right turns are prohibited.

questions.question: Reflective clothing:
questions.answerA: Should be worn only at night.
questions.answerB: Should be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Should be worn both day and night.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur in broad daylight, so wearing brightly-colored, reflective clothing while riding is advised no matter the time of day.

questions.question: When being passed, it is usually best for motorcyclists to be in which part of the lane?
questions.answerA: The right
questions.answerB: The center
questions.answerC: The left
questions.explanation: If you are being passed either from behind or by an oncoming vehicle, stay in the center portion of your lane. Riding any closer to the passing driver could place you both in a hazardous situation.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Always wear a jacket.
questions.answerB: Only wear a jacket at night.
questions.answerC: Only wear a jacket if it is cold outside.
questions.explanation: You should always wear a sturdy jacket with long sleeves when riding a motorcycle, even if the weather is warm.

questions.question: A difference between googles and a windshield is:
questions.answerA: Goggles will protect you from the wind, but a windshield won’t.
questions.answerB: A windshield will protect you from the wind, but goggles won't.
questions.answerC: A windshield will keep your eyes from watering better than goggles.
questions.explanation: Googles will protect your eyes from the wind, but most windshields will not. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for goggles or a face shield.

questions.question: Helmets are:
questions.answerA: Required for all riders.
questions.answerB: Not required, but recommended.
questions.answerC: Only required for inexperienced motorcycle users.
questions.explanation: Georgia law requires riders to wear U.S. Department of Transportation-compliant helmets every time they ride. A helmet is a rider's best defense against head and neck injuries in the event of an accident.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: Two-way traffic
questions.answerB: Right lane ends
questions.answerC: Merge
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions. This sign warns of merging traffic ahead.

questions.question: When riding during the day, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear dark clothes since it is light outside.
questions.answerB: Wear bright clothes so other motorists can see you better.
questions.answerC: Be comfortable, wearing shorts if it is hot.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur in broad daylight. To make yourself more visible to other drivers, you should always wear brightly-colored clothing when riding, even during the day.

questions.question: Pick a lane position that:
questions.answerA: Helps you avoid road hazards.
questions.answerB: Hides you from other road users.
questions.answerC: Places you directly next to another vehicle.
questions.explanation: Choose a lane position that helps you avoid road hazards. Make sure you maintain a safe cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times.

questions.question: You have an improved chance of avoiding serious injury in a crash if you wear:
questions.answerA: Face or eye protection.
questions.answerB: A baseball cap.
questions.answerC: Sneakers.
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet is your best defense against injury while riding a motorcycle. Wearing a plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can help protect your face from injury in a crash.

questions.question: Which of the following factors may affect the blood alcohol content (BAC) of a person?
questions.answerA: The amount of alcohol consumed
questions.answerB: The drinker's height
questions.answerC: The temperature outside
questions.explanation: The three major factors that can affect a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) are the amount of alcohol they have consumed, how quickly they consumed it, and the drinker's body weight.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should always position your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: On the left side of the lane.
questions.answerB: In a position that allows you to most effectively see and be seen.
questions.answerC: In the center of the lane.
questions.explanation: When entering a curve, adjust your lane position to optimize your ability to see and be seen. Riding in the right portion of your lane when traveling through a lefthand curve may help you spot oncoming traffic as soon as possible. When traveling through a righthand curve, riding in a left center position may allow you to see oncoming cars early without putting you so close to the centerline that you could be hit by oncoming vehicles that take the curve too widely.

questions.question: You should conduct a safety inspection of your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerB: Every week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.explanation: You should always conduct a thorough safety inspection of your motorcycle before you ride. A small technical issue on a motorcycle can be more dangerous than a small technical issue on a car.

questions.question: Under normal conditions, a motorcyclist should maintain a following distance of at least:
questions.answerA: Two seconds.
questions.answerB: Three seconds.
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists should maintain a minimum two-second following distance under normal conditions. Any time conditions are less than perfect, a larger following distance is recommended.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, traveling in the left third of the lane allows the driver to see you in their side mirror. What is a downside to this?
questions.answerA: Most people don’t use their side mirrors as often as they use their rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: The wind may prevent the use of a side mirror.
questions.answerC: Side mirrors should not be used by motorists.
questions.explanation: Most drivers do not look at their side mirrors as often as they look at their rearview mirror. Therefore, when following a car, it is generally most advantageous to ride in the center portion of the lane where you are most likely to be visible in the driver's rearview mirror.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Provide you with an escape route.
questions.answerB: Help you receive wind blasts.
questions.answerC: Communicate your intentions to other drivers.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: When buying a motorcycle helmet, you should be most concerned about the helmet's:
questions.answerA: Price.
questions.answerB: Protection.
questions.answerC: Appearance.
questions.explanation: Protection should be your first consideration when buying a motorcycle helmet.

questions.question: When riding at night:
questions.answerA: Only ride in the left portion of the lane to better see around other vehicles ahead.
questions.answerB: Ride closely to the vehicle in front of you to most effectively use their headlights.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed to increase your chances of avoiding an unexpected hazard.
questions.explanation: At night, you should always ride at a lower speed than you would under similar conditions during the day. Doing so will give you a better chance of avoiding hazards. Additionally, increase your following distance and be flexible about your lane position.

questions.question: When motorcyclists ride in a group:
questions.answerA: Inexperienced riders should lead the group.
questions.answerB: Inexperienced riders should be near the front of the group.
questions.answerC: Inexperienced riders should be in the back of the group.
questions.explanation: When traveling in a group, less experienced riders should be placed near the front of the group behind the leader. This way, more experienced riders can lead the way and watch the inexperienced riders at the same time.

questions.question: When riding at night:
questions.answerA: Ride on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, you should increase your following distance. Slow down and be flexible about your lane position.

questions.question: Hearing protection:
questions.answerA: Is not needed when the rider is wearing a helmet.
questions.answerB: Is only recommended for long trips.
questions.answerC: Should be used on all rides.
questions.explanation: Exposure to engine and wind noise can damage your hearing, even if you are wearing a helmet. Wearing hearing protection while riding is always a good idea.

questions.question: The best lane position for a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Is in the left part of a lane, next to the centerline.
questions.answerB: Is in the right part of a lane, next to the curb.
questions.answerC: Can vary depending on road and traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is best at all times. Choose the lane position that allows the most visibility and space around you. Change your lane position as traffic situations change.

questions.question: Reflective, brightly-colored helmets and clothing:
questions.answerA: Should only be worn when riding at night.
questions.answerB: Can help motorcycle riders be more visible.
questions.answerC: Do not increase a motorcycle rider's safety.
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored or reflective clothing can increase your chances of being seen by other road users.

questions.question: Which of the following is not recommended as protective apparel for motorcycle users?
questions.answerA: Long pants
questions.answerB: Gloves
questions.answerC: A baseball cap
questions.explanation: When riding a motorcycle, it is highly recommended that you wear protective apparel. Clothing that may help protect a motorcycle user in the case of a crash include long-sleeved jackets; long, heavy pants; over-the-ankle, closed-toe boots; and full-fingered leather gloves. It is a good idea to cover as much skin as possible when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: If you have only one drink before riding:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: It can affect your ability to operate a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Impairment of riding skills begins with the first drink. If you have consumed alcohol in any amount, it is not safe to ride.

questions.question: A good way to handle a tailgater is to:
questions.answerA: Encourage the tailgater to pass by slowing down or changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerC: Ignore the tailgater.
questions.explanation: If you can do so safely, change lanes and let the tailgater pass. Speeding up may only result in them continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed, increasing the danger.

questions.question: To make it easier to be seen by other motorists, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear brightly-colored clothing while riding.
questions.answerB: Wear darkly-colored clothing while riding.
questions.answerC: Wave your arms while riding.
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing while riding will make it easier for others on the road to see you. This is true regardless of the time of day.

questions.question: You have an improved chance of avoiding serious injury in a crash if you wear:
questions.answerA: Face or eye protection.
questions.answerB: A baseball cap.
questions.answerC: Sneakers.
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet is your best defense against injury while riding a motorcycle. Wearing a plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can help protect your face from injury in a crash.

questions.question: Riding on ______ may provide poor traction.
questions.answerA: Pavement markings
questions.answerB: Dry pavement
questions.answerC: The roadway under a bridge
questions.explanation: Traction may be poor on surfaces such as wet, snowy, icy, or muddy pavement; gravel roads; lane markings; and steel plates and utility hole covers.

questions.question: What type of footwear is the best for motorcycle riders?
questions.answerA: Sneakers
questions.answerB: Leather boots
questions.answerC: Sandals
questions.explanation: Leather boots provide the best degree of protection when riding. They should be high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles.

questions.question: When it starts raining, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Get off the road.
questions.answerB: Ride in the tire tracks left by other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When it starts to rain, avoid riding in the center of the lane. Instead, ride in the tire tracks left by cars ahead of you. The left tire track is often best for riding, but this can vary based on traffic and other conditions.

questions.question: When looking through a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head.
questions.answerC: Turn your head, shoulders, and torso.
questions.explanation: Look through every turn by turning just your head, not your shoulders, and keeping your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Taking a turn too fast can cause a rider to:
questions.answerA: Accidentally end up in another lane of traffic.
questions.answerB: Get through the turn faster.
questions.answerC: Keep control of their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Taking a turn too fast may cause a rider to cross into another lane of traffic, or even leave the road entirely. It is important to slow down before entering a turn or curve.

questions.question: When riding with a group of motorcyclists, a staggered formation:
questions.answerA: Is recommended at all times.
questions.answerB: Should not be used when entering or exiting a highway.
questions.answerC: Should be used when riding in curves.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is generally advisable, a group of motorcyclists should switch to a single-file formation when riding in curves, turning, and entering or leaving a highway.

questions.question: Before riding, a motorcycle operator should check the clutch. A properly working clutch should feel:
questions.answerA: Loose and rough.
questions.answerB: Tight and smooth.
questions.answerC: Loose and smooth.
questions.explanation: Check your clutch and throttle before riding your motorcycle. The throttle should snap back when you let go and the clutch should feel tight and smooth.

questions.question: When being passed from behind, which portion of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerA: Right
questions.answerB: Center
questions.answerC: Left
questions.explanation: When being passed, the center portion of the lane is generally the safest lane position for a motorcyclist. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with it. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle can also be dangerous because it may prompt the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If traveling with a load, the load should be:
questions.answerA: Secured as low as possible.
questions.answerB: Secured as high as possible.
questions.answerC: Attached to a sissy bar.
questions.explanation: If not carried in saddlebags, loads should be secured as low as possible. Attaching a load to a sissy bar can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and upset its balance.

questions.question: Stopping in a turn can be difficult because:
questions.answerA: There is decreased traction available for stopping while the bike is leaning.
questions.answerB: The rider is usually focused on the turn and not on the braking.
questions.answerC: The brake controls do not work in turns.
questions.explanation: It is possible to use both brakes while turning, but it must be done with great care. Some of the usual traction is being used to make the turn while the motorcycle is leaning, so less traction is available for stopping.

questions.question: When scanning the area around your motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Look for potential escape routes near intersections, shopping areas, or schools.
questions.answerB: See if you can travel faster than other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Stare at pedestrians.
questions.explanation: While searching the road for potential hazards, focus on looking for escape routes in or around intersections, shopping areas, schools, and construction zones.

questions.question: If possible, do not ride directly next to another vehicle because:
questions.answerA: Another driver may want to use your lane to pass.
questions.answerB: You may be in the vehicle’s blind spot.
questions.answerC: You may have access to escape routes.
questions.explanation: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is dangerous because you may be in the vehicle's blind spot and the driver will not know you are there. Additionally, the vehicle may block your route of escape if any hazards should arise.

questions.question: You should flash your brake light to:
questions.answerA: Tell other motorists that you are riding near them.
questions.answerB: Help other motorists see your motorcycle while traveling in slow traffic.
questions.answerC: Tell other motorists that you are going to slow down or stop where they don't expect you to do so.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle riders should use their brake lights to communicate with other road users. It is particularly important for a motorcyclist to flash their brake light before slowing down to make a tight, fast turn off of a high-speed roadway. Motorcyclists should flash their brake lights when slowing in any location where other drivers may not expect them to slow down.

questions.question: One problem with a motorcyclist riding directly next to another vehicle is that:
questions.answerA: The other vehicle may block the motorcyclist's escape route.
questions.answerB: The motorcyclist can be easily seen by other drivers.
questions.answerC: The motorcyclist may not be able to read signs on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: Riding alongside another vehicle is dangerous because the vehicle could veer into your lane and sideswipe you. Additionally, the vehicle could block your escape route if a hazard arises.

questions.question: To help others see your motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your headlight.
questions.answerB: Weave in your lane.
questions.answerC: Maintain eye contact with other road users.
questions.explanation: Riding with your headlight activated is the best way to help other road users see your motorcycle. Always be sure your headlight works before starting your trip.

questions.question: You should maintain an increased following distance:
questions.answerA: If the pavement is slippery.
questions.answerB: If traffic is light.
questions.answerC: If you can see through the vehicles in front of you to determine traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a minimum four-second following distance.

questions.question: Which brake is more powerful on a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: The front brake
questions.answerB: The rear brake
questions.answerC: Both brakes are equally powerful.
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful that the rear brake and can provide at least 70 percent of the bike's total stopping power.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection:
questions.answerA: Takes only minutes.
questions.answerB: Takes about an hour.
questions.answerC: Should only be done by a certified mechanic.
questions.explanation: You should do a pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This will usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: Your motorcycle should fit you, meaning:
questions.answerA: Your fingertips should barely reach the handlebars when you are seated on the motorcycle.
questions.answerB: The seat should be one foot higher than your waist when you are standing next to the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Your feet should comfortably reach the ground when you are seated on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle fits you appropriately if your feet comfortably reach the ground while you are seated. Be sure a motorcycle fits you before riding.

questions.question: When traveling in a group, riders should generally be:
questions.answerA: In a single-file formation.
questions.answerB: Paired up.
questions.answerC: In a staggered formation.
questions.explanation: In general, a staggered formation is the best way for a group of riders to maintain close ranks while allowing adequate space cushions for each rider. A single-file formation is best when taking curves, turning, entering a highway, or exiting a highway.

questions.question: A motorized scooter can:
questions.answerA: Only be operated during the day.
questions.answerB: Be operated without a driver license.
questions.answerC: Be operated with any class of driver license.
questions.explanation: In California, motorized scooter can be used by anyone possessing any class of driver license.

questions.question: When attempting to pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride within the posted speed limits.
questions.answerB: Exceed the posted speed limit to complete the pass, but not by more than 10 mph.
questions.answerC: Pass more than one vehicle at a time.
questions.explanation: All passes must be completed within legal speed limits. Riders should pass only where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should include all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A tire check.
questions.answerB: A test of the turn signals.
questions.answerC: A paint inspection.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your motorcycle before a ride, be sure to check the tires, controls, lights, signals, mirrors, brakes, oil, fluids, chassis, and stands.

questions.question: Mirrors on motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Have blind spots, just like cars.
questions.answerB: Do not have blind spots.
questions.answerC: Are not required.
questions.explanation: The mirrors of motorcycles have blind spots, just like those of cars. Always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: When riding near a truck:
questions.answerA: If you cannot see the truck’s mirrors, the driver cannot see you.
questions.answerB: You should not be able to see the truck’s mirrors.
questions.answerC: You should concentrate on operating your motorcycle and not worry about the truck’s mirrors.
questions.explanation: It is important for motorcyclists to avoid lingering in the blind spots of any vehicle, especially in those of large trucks. Remember that if you can't see the truck's mirrors, the driver can't see you.

questions.question: When positioning your body on the motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You should hold yourself up with your arms.
questions.answerB: Your arms should be used to steer the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: You should have to stretch to reach the handgrips.
questions.explanation: To have proper riding posture, position yourself so that you are using your arms to steer rather than to hold yourself up. Sit so that your elbows are slightly bent when you hold the handgrips.

questions.question: When carrying a load, it should be:
questions.answerA: Secured as high as possible.
questions.answerB: Secured as low as possible.
questions.answerC: Secured on a sissy bar.
questions.explanation: Loads should be secured low in order to avoid upsetting the motorcycle's balance.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to weave while you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to get over the surface faster.
questions.answerB: Exaggerate the zigzag motion to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerC: Maintain a steady speed and ride straight across the grooves or gratings.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle begins to weave when riding over grooves or gratings, simply maintain a steady speed and proceed straight across the surface. Trying to compensate for the weave by riding at an angle forces you to zigzag to stay in your lane, which is more dangerous.

questions.question: To improve your chances of being seen, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your headlight only at night or when conditions reduce visibility.
questions.answerB: Always use your headlight.
questions.answerC: Add an orange tint to your headlight.
questions.explanation: The single most effective thing you can do to help others see your motorcycle is ride with your headlight on at all times.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Scan your path ahead.
questions.answerB: Be ready to act to avoid a hazard.
questions.answerC: Turn your headlight off during the day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: As you consume more alcohol, your ability to safely ride:
questions.answerA: Increases.
questions.answerB: Stays the same.
questions.answerC: Decreases.
questions.explanation: The skills a person needs to ride safely decrease as the amount of alcohol consumed increases. If you have consumed alcohol in any amount, it is safest not to ride your motorcycle.

questions.question: You will get the most protection from a helmet if it is all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: U.S. DOT-compliant.
questions.answerB: Loose-fitting.
questions.answerC: Free of defects.
questions.explanation: A helmet will provide a rider with the best protection if it meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards; fits snugly all the way around; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: Helmets are:
questions.answerA: Required for all riders.
questions.answerB: Not required, but recommended.
questions.answerC: Only required for inexperienced motorcycle users.
questions.explanation: Georgia law requires riders to wear U.S. Department of Transportation-compliant helmets every time they ride. A helmet is a rider's best defense against head and neck injuries in the event of an accident.

questions.question: When wearing a helmet at the time of a crash, a rider is:
questions.answerA: Less likely to survive than a person who is not wearing helmet.
questions.answerB: Just as likely to survive as a person not wearing a helmet.
questions.answerC: More likely to survive than a person not wearing helmet.
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, a motorcycle rider has an advantage over an automobile driver because:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle can accelerate more quickly than a car.
questions.answerB: The motorcyclist can ride in the left part of the lane to avoid people and cars to their right.
questions.answerC: Motorcycles have a shorter stopping distance than cars do.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked vehicles to your right, you may ride in the left portion of your lane. This way, you can more easily avoid opening doors, drivers getting out of vehicles, or people stepping out from between vehicles. Only ride in the left portion of the lane if there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: For motorcycle operators, helmets are:
questions.answerA: Required.
questions.answerB: Not required, but recommended.
questions.answerC: Not recommended.
questions.explanation: In Georgia, you are required to wear a U.S. Department of Transportation-compliant helmet any time you operate a motorcycle.

questions.question: Reflective, brightly-colored helmets and clothing:
questions.answerA: Should only be worn when riding at night.
questions.answerB: Can help motorcycle riders be more visible.
questions.answerC: Do not increase a motorcycle rider's safety.
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored or reflective clothing can increase your chances of being seen by other road users.

questions.question: You have an improved chance of surviving a crash if you wear:
questions.answerA: A DOT-compliant helmet.
questions.answerB: A baseball cap.
questions.answerC: Comfortable shoes.
questions.explanation: You will get the most head and neck protection from a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. The single most effective thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving a crash is wear a properly secured, good-quality helmet.

questions.question: If you will be carrying a passenger on your motorcycle, you will likely have to:
questions.answerA: Reduce the tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Make no tire pressure adjustments.
questions.answerC: Increase the tire pressure.
questions.explanation: Because a passenger will place additional weight on your motorcycle, you will probably need to add a few pounds of pressure to your tires before riding. Check your owner's manual for details regarding the appropriate pressure settings to use.

questions.question: How do convex mirrors differ from regular mirrors?
questions.answerA: They provide a more narrow view of the road.
questions.answerB: They provide a wider view of the road.
questions.answerC: They provide a better view of the road.
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors are installed on many motorcycles. Compared to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road. However, convex mirrors can also make approaching vehicles seem farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: A benefit of keeping a cushion of space between you and surrounding vehicles is that:
questions.answerA: You are better able to draft off of other vehicles.
questions.answerB: You will be able to stop quickly.
questions.answerC: You will have more time to react to the movements of other drivers.
questions.explanation: It is important to maintain a cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times. This way, if a hazard arises, you will have more time to respond to the hazard and more space to safely maneuver.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked cars, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride on the left side of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride wherever you are most comfortable.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, the left portion of the lane is generally safest for travel. This position will help you avoid hazards like doors being opened, people stepping out from between the parked cars, and cars pulling out of parking spaces. Always be ready to adjust your lane position to respond to changing road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerC: Decrease your following distance.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: Railroad crossing ahead
questions.answerB: Yield
questions.answerC: Reduce speed
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions. This sign warns that a railroad crossing is ahead.

questions.question: What should be your first consideration when buying a motorcycle helmet?
questions.answerA: Appearance
questions.answerB: Protection
questions.answerC: Price
questions.explanation: Protection should be your first consideration when buying a motorcycle helmet. Look for a helmet that fastens securely, fits correctly, and is DOT-compliant.

questions.question: Under normal conditions, a motorcyclist should maintain a following distance of at least:
questions.answerA: Two seconds.
questions.answerB: Three seconds.
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists should maintain a minimum two-second following distance under normal conditions. Any time conditions are less than perfect, a larger following distance is recommended.

questions.question: Motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Need less room to stop than other larger vehicles.
questions.answerB: Need as much room to stop as other larger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Can stop instantly.
questions.explanation: A rider should always maintain a cushion of space appropriate for conditions. Motorcycles need as much room to stop as other vehicles.

questions.question: When sitting on a motorcycle, your arms should:
questions.answerA: Have a large bend at the elbow when reaching for the handle grips.
questions.answerB: Be slightly bent when holding the handle grips.
questions.answerC: Be fully extended when reaching for the handle grips.
questions.explanation: Your arms should be slightly bent when you are holding the handle grips of a motorcycle. Bending your arms reduces arm fatigue and permits you to press on the handlebars without having to stretch.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: The mirrors provide a perfect view.
questions.answerB: The mirrors do not show your blind spots.
questions.answerC: The mirrors should not be used, except when parking.
questions.explanation: As with any other vehicle, the mirrors of a motorcycle have blind spots. Always turn your head to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: When riding during the day, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear dark clothes since it is light outside.
questions.answerB: Wear bright clothes so other motorists can see you better.
questions.answerC: Be comfortable, wearing shorts if it is hot.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur in broad daylight. To make yourself more visible to other drivers, you should always wear brightly-colored clothing when riding, even during the day.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: The front brake is more powerful than the rear brake.
questions.answerB: The rear brake is more powerful than the front brake.
questions.answerC: Both the front and rear brakes are equally powerful.
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: How should a group of motorcyclists pass another vehicle?
questions.answerA: In a staggered formation
questions.answerB: In pairs
questions.answerC: One at a time
questions.explanation: On a two-lane road, a group of motorcyclists should pass another vehicle one at a time. Each motorcyclist should complete the pass before another begins to pass.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should be:
questions.answerA: In the front.
questions.answerB: Just behind the lead rider.
questions.answerC: In the rear.
questions.explanation: In a group, less experienced riders should be positioned toward the front, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders to watch them from behind.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger on your motorcycle, you should instruct the passenger to:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle before the engine starts.
questions.answerB: Sit as far back as possible on the bike.
questions.answerC: Not talk or move unnecessarily.
questions.explanation: Tell passengers to avoid unnecessary conversation or movement while on a moving motorcycle. Passengers should get onto a motorcycle only after the engine is started. They should sit as far forward as possible without crowding the operator.

questions.question: When turning, you should:
questions.answerA: Move your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head, not your shoulders, to look through the turn.
questions.answerC: Turn your head and shoulders to look through the turn.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon. Turning your shoulders may cause you to steer off course.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Provide a narrow view of the road behind you.
questions.answerB: Provide a wide view of the road behind you.
questions.answerC: Are illegal.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. Take the time to get used to your mirrors if your motorcycle is equipped with convex mirrors.

questions.question: When you are being passed on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed on your left, you should ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding in the right portion of the lane can be dangerous as it may tempt the passing driver to re-enter your lane too quickly.

questions.question: Grabbing at the front brake or jamming down on the rear brake:
questions.answerA: Can cause the brakes to lock.
questions.answerB: Is the best way to stop in an emergency.
questions.answerC: Is the best way to slow down when the streets are wet.
questions.explanation: Grabbing at the front brake or jamming down on the rear brake can cause the brakes to lock. This may result in control problems.

questions.question: When riding, your feet should be:
questions.answerA: On the gas tank.
questions.answerB: Hanging loosely.
questions.answerC: On the footrests.
questions.explanation: Your feet should remain on your footrests while riding to help you maintain proper balance.

questions.question: When being followed by a tailgater, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow them to pass.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Not change how you are riding.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to allow them to pass you. Speeding up may result in them continuing to tailgate you, just at a higher speed.

questions.question: If a motorcycle rider takes a turn too fast, they may:
questions.answerA: Have increased control of their motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Experience a more stable ride.
questions.answerC: Unintentionally leave the road.
questions.explanation: Taking a turn or curve too fast may cause a rider to lose control of their motorcycle. The motorcycle may cross into another lane of traffic or careen off the road.

questions.question: If your rear wheel locks up while you are stopping on a surface with good traction, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the wheel locked until you have stopped completely.
questions.answerB: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake and then quickly re-apply the brake.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear wheel while stopping on a surface with good traction, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped. Even with a locked rear wheel, you can control your motorcycle if it is upright and traveling in a straight line.

questions.question: When riding, jackets and pants should:
questions.answerA: Fit loosely enough to allow the wind to catch the fabric.
questions.answerB: Be snug enough to keep from flapping in the wind.
questions.answerC: Be tight enough to prevent you from moving freely.
questions.explanation: Jackets and pants should fit snugly enough that they do not flap in the wind, but also loosely enough that you are able to move freely.

questions.question: If your front wheel locks while you are braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the tire locked until your next stop.
questions.answerB: Continue squeezing the front brake lever.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake and immediately re-apply it.
questions.explanation: If the front wheel locks up while you are braking, release the pressure from the front brake. Immediately re-apply pressure to the brake with controlled gradual pressure.

questions.question: When stopping, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both brakes.
questions.answerB: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerC: Use the rear brake only.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to get into the habit of using both the front and rear brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: When stopping your motorcycle while carrying a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride a little faster than you normally would.
questions.answerB: Start slowing earlier than you normally would.
questions.answerC: Merge into smaller gaps of traffic than you normally would.
questions.explanation: A passenger places extra weight on a motorcycle. Because of the added weight, the motorcycle will respond to the operator's movements more slowly than it would otherwise, taking more time to speed up, slow down, and turn. To accommodate the change in handling when carrying a passenger, you should reduce your speed, begin slowing down earlier when you stop, and look for larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging into traffic.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerA: Hold onto the rider's hips, waist, or belt.
questions.answerB: Never hold onto the rider.
questions.answerC: Not lean into any turn.
questions.explanation: Before beginning your ride, tell your passenger to maintain a firm grasp on your hips, waist, or belt. If there are secure handholds for your passenger, they may also hold those.

questions.question: When looking through a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn just your head, not your shoulders.
questions.answerB: Turn your head and shoulders to improve your view.
questions.answerC: Turn your shoulders, but not your head.
questions.explanation: When taking a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When being followed by a tailgater, you should:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass or slow down to allow for more space ahead of your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Ignore them.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed by a tailgater, you should ride in a way that encourages them to pass you. Riding at a higher speed may only result in them tailgating you at a higher speed, increasing the danger.

questions.question: If a motorcycle is towing a trailer, the motorcyclist's following distance should:
questions.answerA: Increase.
questions.answerB: Decrease.
questions.answerC: Be the same as it normally would be.
questions.explanation: A motorcyclist who is towing a trailer should increase their following distance. The added weight of the trailer means that the motorcycle will require more time to stop than it would otherwise.

questions.question: Which colors are the best colors for motorcycle riders to wear?
questions.answerA: Brown, gold, silver, and white
questions.answerB: Blue, black, gray, and purple
questions.answerC: Orange, red, yellow, and green
questions.explanation: Bright oranges, reds, yellows, and greens are the best colors for motorcyclists to wear. These colors can help other road users see motorcyclists.

questions.question: If you must stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerA: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerB: Use the front brake first.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake at the same time as the rear brake.
questions.explanation: The best way to stop quickly is to apply controlled pressure to both the rear and front brakes at the same time. Be careful not to lock the brakes in the process.

questions.question: You are most likely to get into a collision:
questions.answerA: At an intersection.
questions.answerB: When riding in a group.
questions.answerC: Traveling on the expressway.
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between you and other traffic exists at intersections.

questions.question: A difference between googles and a windshield is:
questions.answerA: Goggles will protect you from the wind, but a windshield won’t.
questions.answerB: A windshield will protect you from the wind, but goggles won't.
questions.answerC: A windshield will keep your eyes from watering better than goggles.
questions.explanation: Googles will protect your eyes from the wind, but most windshields will not. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for goggles or a face shield.

questions.question: The proper action to take when riding an unfamiliar motorcycle for the first time is to:
questions.answerA: Just start riding. There is no better way to learn than by doing.
questions.answerB: Just start riding. Most bikes are similar, so you don’t have to take the time to identify safety features.
questions.answerC: Work the throttle, clutch, and brakes before riding to learn the bike's gear pattern.
questions.explanation: Every bike is a little different, so don't start riding an unfamiliar motorcycle without first familiarizing yourself with how it operates. Do a safety and maintenance check; find out where everything is located; and work the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times to learn its gear pattern.

questions.question: Under normal riding conditions, one of the best ways to help others see your motorcycle is:
questions.answerA: To flash your lights.
questions.answerB: To keep your high beam headlight turned on.
questions.answerC: To ensure that your motorcycle is painted a dark color.
questions.explanation: The best way to help others see your motorcycle is to have your headlight turned on (as well as your running lights, if applicable). Use your high beam headlight both day and night, whenever it is legal and safe to do so.

questions.question: The formation you should take when riding in a group:
questions.answerA: Is always single-file.
questions.answerB: Depends on the situation.
questions.answerC: Is always staggered.
questions.explanation: In general, it is best for a group to ride in a staggered formation. Move into a single-file formation when taking a curve, making a turn, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.

questions.question: To minimize the potential for fatigue, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on the radio.
questions.answerB: Take frequent rest breaks.
questions.answerC: Drink caffeine.
questions.explanation: Taking frequent rest breaks during a long trip can help reduce fatigue. Stimulants, such as caffeine, can ultimately increase the danger of fatigue because you may become extremely tired when they begin to wear off. Wind, rain, snow, and other elements can also increase levels of fatigue, so dress warmly (as needed) and invest in a windshield, especially if you plan to ride long distances.

questions.question: Usually a good way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Get off the roadway.
questions.answerB: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Ride faster.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle tailgaters is usually to change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by prompting them to continue tailgating you at the higher speed.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should not rely only on their mirrors because:
questions.answerA: Sometimes mirrors can be dirty, limiting the motorcyclist's view.
questions.answerB: Mirrors are always unreliable.
questions.answerC: Motorcycles have blind spots.
questions.explanation: To remain aware of your surroundings, it is not enough to rely only on your mirrors. Motorcycles have blind spots just like any other vehicle.

questions.question: When entering a turn, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Change gears before the turn.
questions.answerB: Change gears during the turn.
questions.answerC: Take the motorcycle out of gear.
questions.explanation: It is best to change gears before entering a turn. If you must change gears while in a turn, be sure to do so smoothly.

questions.question: To reduce the chances of a collision, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear bright or reflective clothing.
questions.answerB: Change lanes frequently.
questions.answerC: Focus only on your riding, not on your surroundings.
questions.explanation: Wearing bright or reflective clothing can help make you more visible to other drivers and reduce your risk of being involved in a collision. Always maintain an awareness of surrounding drivers to better prepare yourself for their movements.

questions.question: If vehicles or other potential hazards are to your right, you should ride on which side of your lane?
questions.answerA: Right
questions.answerB: Left
questions.answerC: Either side
questions.explanation: When riding on the road, position yourself in a manner that allows you the most possible space. If there are hazards to your left, ride on the right side of your lane. If there are hazards to you right, ride on the left side of your lane.

questions.question: You are riding over bridge gratings and your motorcycle has begun to weave. You should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to get over the surface faster.
questions.answerB: Ride in a zigzagging motion.
questions.answerC: Maintain a steady speed and ride straight across the gratings.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle begins to weave while you are traveling over bridge gratings, you should simply maintain a steady speed and proceed straight across the surface. Trying to stay in your lane while riding in a zigzagging motion is dangerous.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: Yield
questions.answerB: Slow-moving vehicle
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing
questions.explanation: This sign is displayed on the rear of slow-moving vehicles that may be moving more slowly than 25 mph, such as construction equipment, farm machinery, or horse-drawn vehicles.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should attempt to avoid obstacles on the roadway. If avoiding an obstacle is not possible, the motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Speed up before coming into contact with the object.
questions.answerB: Stay seated so the seat can cushion some of the impact.
questions.answerC: Try to approach the obstacle at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible.
questions.explanation: If you are unable to avoid an obstacle and must instead ride over it, you should slow down and approach the obstacle at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible.

questions.question: If another driver makes eye contact with you:
questions.answerA: You know that they have seen you.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t always mean they've actually seen you.
questions.answerC: They will properly yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never rely on eye contact as an assurance that a driver has seen you. It is not uncommon for a driver to look directly at a motorcyclist and still fail to actually notice them.

questions.question: As your motorcycle accelerates, you will need to:
questions.answerA: Shift to a higher gear.
questions.answerB: Shift to a lower gear.
questions.answerC: Put the bike in neutral.
questions.explanation: As your motorcycle accelerates, you will need to shift into a higher gear.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, traveling in the center portion of the lane:
questions.answerA: Allows you to be seen in its rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Usually makes it difficult for the driver to see you.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided.
questions.explanation: When following a car, you should ride in a position that allows the driver to see you in their rearview mirror. Usually, that means riding in the center portion of the lane. Because most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than they check their side mirrors, being in this lane position increases the chance that they will see you.

questions.question: Upshifting or downshifting in a curve:
questions.answerA: Should only be done if it can be done smoothly.
questions.answerB: Is better than shifting before the curve.
questions.answerC: Is the best way to control your speed.
questions.explanation: It is best to change gears before starting a turn. However, if you must shift while turning, shift smoothly. A sudden change in power to the rear wheel can cause a skid.

questions.question: Before every ride, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure your bike's brake lights work properly.
questions.answerB: Make sure the paint on the bike is not peeling.
questions.answerC: Make sure your bike is completely clean.
questions.explanation: Perform safety checks before every motorcycle ride. Test your brake controls individually to make sure each one activates the brake lights.

questions.question: A rider's boots or shoes should:
questions.answerA: Be below their ankles.
questions.answerB: Cover their ankles.
questions.answerC: Be made of a soft, pliable material.
questions.explanation: For riding, choose footwear that is sturdy and high enough to cover and support your ankles. Soles should be made of hard, durable, slip-resistant material.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Provide you with an escape route.
questions.answerB: Help you receive wind blasts.
questions.answerC: Communicate your intentions to other drivers.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: To minimize the potential for fatigue on a long trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Drink coffee.
questions.answerB: Limit your riding per day.
questions.answerC: Play loud music.
questions.explanation: When taking a long trip, be sure to schedule in frequent breaks to rest, even if you do not feel tired. Experienced operators seldom try to ride for longer than six hours a day. Wind, cold, and rain can make you tire quickly, so be sure to dress to protect yourself from the elements.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Move into the portion of the lane that will bring you into another driver’s field of vision at the earliest possible moment.
questions.answerB: Stop at the stop sign or signal and then proceed normally.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights and sound your horn to alert other drivers to your presence.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection, move into the portion of the lane that will bring you into another driver’s field of vision at the earliest possible moment.

questions.question: When choosing a jacket for protection, you should ensure that it:
questions.answerA: Fits loosely and flaps in the wind.
questions.answerB: Fits snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind.
questions.answerC: Is it not made of leather or another sturdy material.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should choose pants and a jacket made of leather or another sturdy material. They should fit you snugly enough that they do not flap in the wind, but also loosely enough that they let you move freely.

questions.question: A DOT-compliant helmet:
questions.answerA: Severely limits your vision.
questions.answerB: Allows you to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding.
questions.answerC: Can become a hazard to the rider.
questions.explanation: While some people believe that a helmet will limit their vision, this is not the case. Any U.S. Department of Transportation-approved helmet will allow the wearer to see as far as is needed for safe riding.

questions.question: When you are being passed, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side nearest the passing driver increases the danger of colliding with them, and riding on the side farthest from the driver may tempt them to return to your lane too soon.

questions.question: Smaller vehicles appear to be ________ and slower than they really are.
questions.answerA: Closer
questions.answerB: Farther away
questions.answerC: Larger
questions.explanation: It can be difficult to judge the speed and distance of a small vehicle, such as a motorcycle. Do not assume that drivers of larger vehicles will be able to accurately understand your speed and location.

questions.question: What can remove alcohol from a person's system?
questions.answerA: Time
questions.answerB: Coffee
questions.answerC: Exercise
questions.explanation: The only way to sober up after drinking is to give your body the time it needs to remove the alcohol. There are no techniques that will speed up this process.

questions.question: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use turn signals.
questions.answerB: Use proper lane positions.
questions.answerC: Follow other vehicles closely.
questions.explanation: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should make yourself visible, communicate your intentions to others, maintain adequate space cushions, search your path of travel at least 12 seconds ahead, identify and separate hazards, and be prepared to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: When riding behind another vehicle, you should position yourself:
questions.answerA: To be seen in the vehicle’s side mirror.
questions.answerB: To be seen in the vehicle’s rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: To be seen through the vehicle's passenger window.
questions.explanation: If you are following a car, the driver is most likely to notice you if you position yourself behind them in the center of your lane. This lane position places you in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors.

questions.question: If you borrow a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume all controls are in the same location as they are on your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Immediately take it out on the highway.
questions.answerC: Get familiar with it in a controlled area.
questions.explanation: All motorcycles are at least somewhat different. Before riding a motorcycle that is new to you, take the time to learn where all of the controls are. Ride the motorcycle in a controlled area to get used to it before taking it out on the road.

questions.question: When passing a vehicle, you:
questions.answerA: May exceed the speed limit by 10 mph.
questions.answerB: Must not exceed the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Are required to ride faster than the speed limit.
questions.explanation: Passing must be completed within posted speed limits. Only pass another vehicle where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: If the front wheel locks, you should:
questions.answerA: Release the front brake immediately, then re-apply the brake.
questions.answerB: Release the front brake immediately and only use the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Keep the front wheel locked until you come to a stop.
questions.explanation: If you lock the front wheel while braking, release the brake and immediately re-apply it.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid danger, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the front brake while swerving.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve, you should take these actions separately. Never brake while swerving because doing so can cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: To control a motorcycle well, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your arms to hold yourself up.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank.
questions.answerC: Sit so your arms are straight when reaching for the handlebars.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should be seated so you can use your arms to steer rather than to hold yourself up. Your elbows should be slightly bent when you hold the handgrips. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance.

questions.question: What does an integrated braking system do?
questions.answerA: It links the front and rear brakes together when the rear brake is applied.
questions.answerB: It knows when to brake automatically by understanding your riding habits.
questions.answerC: It is connected to the gears and applies the brake when downshifting.
questions.explanation: Some motorcycles have integrated braking systems that link the front and rear brakes together when the rider applies the rear brake pedal. It is important to consult your owner's manual for details on your specific motorcycle's braking system.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a reason to keep a cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you?
questions.answerA: It allows you more time to respond to hazards.
questions.answerB: It prevents you from finding an escape route.
questions.answerC: It provides space to maneuver your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Maintaining an adequate space cushion ensures that you will have time to respond if another driver makes a mistake. A cushion of space also allows you the space you need to safely maneuver your motorcycle.

questions.question: For motorcycle operators, eye protection is:
questions.answerA: Required.
questions.answerB: Not required, but recommended.
questions.answerC: Not recommended.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle operators are required to use proper eye protection when riding in Georgia.

questions.question: Locking your brakes can:
questions.answerA: Be helpful in most situations.
questions.answerB: Improve steering.
questions.answerC: Cause control problems.
questions.explanation: Locking the brakes can cause control problems. If your front brake locks, you should release the brake then immediately re-apply it. If you lock your rear brake when stopping on a good traction surface, keep it locked until you have completely stopped.

questions.question: The Motorcycle Safety Foundation recommends a SEE strategy to make safe judgments while riding. What does "SEE" stand for?
questions.answerA: Search, Evaluate, and Execute.
questions.answerB: Slow, Experienced, and Error-free.
questions.answerC: Safe, Experienced, and Evasive.
questions.explanation: Experienced riders use a SEE strategy while riding to make safe judgements. "SEE" stands for Search, Evaluate, and Execute.

questions.question: When parked on the road, a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Create an angle with the curb that is between 45 and 90 degrees.
questions.answerB: Be parked without a wheel or fender touching the curb.
questions.answerC: Be parked parallel to the curb.
questions.explanation: When parked on the road, a motorcycle should create an angle with the curb that is between 45 and 90 degrees. A wheel or fender should be touching the curb.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to be seen.
questions.answerB: Help you avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerC: Invite other road users into your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: Right lane ends
questions.answerB: Left lane ends
questions.answerC: Traffic control device ahead
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions. This sign warns that the right lane ends ahead.

questions.question: When riding at night, maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerA: Two seconds.
questions.answerB: Three seconds.
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Because it can be difficult to judge distances in the dark, ride with a following distance of at least three seconds when traveling at night.

questions.question: When it starts to rain, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerC: Pull to the side of the road until the rain stops.
questions.explanation: When it starts to rain, the oily strip down the center of a lane is especially hazardous. Avoid this danger by riding in the tire tracks left by cars. The left tire track is often safest, but this can vary.

questions.question: A passenger on a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Put their feet on the ground when the motorcycle is stopped.
questions.answerB: Not ride without a back rest.
questions.answerC: Sit as far forward as possible without crowding the operator.
questions.explanation: A passenger on a motorcycle should sit as far forward as possible without crowding the operator. The passenger should keep both feet on the footrests at all times, even when stopped.

questions.question: To properly control a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow your feet to hang off the footrests.
questions.answerB: Sit so your arms hold up your body.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees against the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should be positioned so that you are able to easily operate all controls. Sit with your arms slightly bent and use your arms to steer rather than to hold up your body. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance during turns.

questions.question: There is the greatest potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other traffic:
questions.answerA: On the highway.
questions.answerB: At intersections.
questions.answerC: On rural roads.
questions.explanation: Intersections present the greatest potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other vehicles. Motorcyclists should exercise caution when approaching an intersection.

questions.question: It is illegal to operate a motorcycle with a minimum blood alcohol content (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerB: 0.1 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.3 percent.
questions.explanation: In California, it is illegal for a person age 21 or older to operate a motorcycle with a blood alcohol content (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. For a person under the age of 21, it is illegal to operate a motorcycle with a BAC of 0.01 percent or higher. It may be unsafe to operate a motorcycle even if you are under the legal limit.

questions.question: A solid white line on the side of the road indicates:
questions.answerA: No parking is permitted.
questions.answerB: The right edge of a traffic lane.
questions.answerC: Traffic must merge.
questions.explanation: A solid white line on the side of the road is used to indicate the right edge of a traffic lane.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to weave while riding over uneven metal bridge gratings, you should:
questions.answerA: Downshift immediately to a lower gear.
questions.answerB: Proceed in a zigzag pattern until you cross the bridge.
questions.answerC: Relax and steer straight.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle begins to weave while riding over uneven rain grooves or bridge gratings, simply relax and proceed straight across the grooves at a steady speed. Steering in a zigzag pattern as you cross gratings is more dangerous than the weaving.

questions.question: To swerve correctly, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerB: Turn the handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To swerve away from a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the handgrip located on the side of your intended escape.

questions.question: The gearshift is located:
questions.answerA: By the left footrest.
questions.answerB: By the right footrest.
questions.answerC: By the right handle grip.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever of a motorcycle is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the rider's left foot.

questions.question: To reduce the chances of a collision, a motorcycle rider should:
questions.answerA: Maintain an adequate space cushion.
questions.answerB: Ride very slowly.
questions.answerC: Ride the centerline.
questions.explanation: To reduce your chances of being involved in a collision, always allow yourself an adequate cushion of space. Maintain your space cushion when following another vehicle, being followed by another vehicle, passing, being passed, or lane sharing.

questions.question: A motorcycle’s brake light is _________ a passenger vehicle’s brake light.
questions.answerA: More noticeable than
questions.answerB: Just as noticeable as
questions.answerC: Not as noticeable as
questions.explanation: Your motorcycle’s brake light is usually not as noticeable as that of a larger vehicle, especially when the taillight is on. Be aware that surrounding drivers may not notice your brake light.

questions.question: You should conduct a safety inspection of your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerB: Every week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.explanation: You should always conduct a thorough safety inspection of your motorcycle before you ride. A small technical issue on a motorcycle can be more dangerous than a small technical issue on a car.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between you and other vehicles?
questions.answerA: At an intersection
questions.answerB: On the highway
questions.answerC: On any road
questions.explanation: The potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other vehicles is greatest at intersections.

questions.question: The normal recommended following distance should be extended if:
questions.answerA: The pavement is slippery.
questions.answerB: The sun is shining.
questions.answerC: You believe stopping will be routine.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up your following distance.

questions.question: What does a traffic signal displaying a solid red arrow mean?
questions.answerA: Drivers must come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Drivers may proceed through the intersection with caution.
questions.answerC: Drivers must yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: A traffic signal displaying a solid red arrow has the same meaning as a red traffic light. Drivers must come to a complete stop and wait for a traffic signal that allows them to turn in their desired direction.

questions.question: Service signs are:
questions.answerA: Orange with black letters.
questions.answerB: Blue with white letters.
questions.answerC: Green with white letters.
questions.explanation: Signs that are blue with white markings indicate the locations of services. These services may include rest areas, gas stations, food options, and hospitals.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerA: Look over their shoulder when taking a turn or curve.
questions.answerB: Never hold onto the rider.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.explanation: Before mounting, you should ask your passenger to look over your shoulder in the direction of any turn or curve that you may take. Doing so will help you and your bike to lean in the appropriate direction.

questions.question: When starting your motorcycle, the engine should be in:
questions.answerA: First gear.
questions.answerB: Neutral.
questions.answerC: Third gear.
questions.explanation: Make sure your motorcycle's transmission is in neutral before you start the engine. Most motorcycles have a neutral indicator on the speedometer that lights up when the ignition switch is on and the cycle is in neutral.

questions.question: Mirrors on motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Have blind spots, just like cars.
questions.answerB: Do not have blind spots because a motorcycle is usually smaller than a car
questions.answerC: Are not required.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like cars. You should always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: When stopping, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both brakes.
questions.answerB: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerC: Use the rear brake only.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes every time you slow or stop. It is important to be able to brake quickly by using both brakes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a potential problem?
questions.answerA: An upcoming change in road surface characteristics
questions.answerB: Surrounding traffic
questions.answerC: Conditions that do not appear to change as you approach
questions.explanation: Anticipate potential problems that can be created by factors on the roadway. Make a plan to reduce their risks.

questions.question: When passing a truck on a two-lane road, you should:
questions.answerA: Not return to your original lane until you can see the front of the truck in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Return to your original lane as soon as the truck is behind you.
questions.answerC: Return to your original lane when you feel you have enough space.
questions.explanation: When passing a truck, you should only return to your original lane when you can see the entire front of the truck in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: When braking on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: The rear brake should be applied first.
questions.answerB: The front brake should be applied first.
questions.answerC: The front and rear brakes should be applied at the same time.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes every time you slow down or stop. If you use only the rear brake when stopping normally, you may not develop the habit or the skill to use the front brake properly when you really need to stop quickly.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: Slippery when wet
questions.answerB: Lanes shift
questions.answerC: Yield
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions. This sign warns that the roadway ahead is likely to be slippery when wet.

questions.question: When it starts to rain, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull onto the shoulder and wait for it to stop raining.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Roads become slippery when it first starts raining, especially in the center strip of a lane. When rain starts, it is generally safest to ride in the tire tracks left by other vehicles. The left tire track is often best.

questions.question: Footrests:
questions.answerA: May be shared by the driver and passenger
questions.answerB: Are required for the driver and passenger
questions.answerC: Are not required
questions.explanation: Keep your feet firmly on the footrests for balance. The motorcycle should be equipped with passenger footrests. Firm footing prevents your passenger from falling off and pulling you off, too.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: Your mirrors can adequately show you your surroundings.
questions.answerB: Do a head check in addition to using your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Activate your turn signal and immediately move to the right or left.
questions.explanation: Like any vehicle, motorcycles have blind spots. In addition to using your mirrors, you must always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes.
